data.title: EnableDefaultLighting issue with DesktopGL
data.body:
Hello there:

I encountered the issues with the lighting features of the Effects in the 3.5.1.1679 for DesktopGL.

The BasicEffect lighting does not seem to apply.
I used: `Effect.EnableDefaultLighting();` and `Effect.LightingEnabled = true;`
to light primitive with two triangles and PNG texture (also not work with other formats).

![tz8hu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16684828/17106142/e8e3bca4-5292-11e6-9c3c-a0d38a9e029f.jpg)

Original texture is colorful:
![20m1j](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16684828/17106163/02a7b83e-5293-11e6-91b5-577fffcd59eb.png)
When I remove `Effect.EnableDefaultLighting();` and `Effect.LightingEnabled = true;` colors are showed normal, but with no light of course. It working fine with the DefaultLighting on my host Windows 7 machine, but it not working as I described on another machines with Windows 7 and Windows 10.

On host machine with no problems:
- DLL's in the C:\Program Files (x86)\MonoGame\v3.0\Assemblies\DesktopGL path are 3.5.1.1679
- DLL's in the C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\MonoGame\v3.0\Tools are 3.5.1.1679
- DLL's in the Debug\ path are 3.5.1.1679

loaded assemblies when dubug(listed only with differences):
- mscorlib.dll 4.6.1076
- System.Core.dll 4.6.1055.0
- System.dll 4.6.1075.0 
- System.Drawing.dll 4.6.1068.2 
- System.Windows.Forms.dll 4.6.1055.0 

On another Windows 10(any version of Windows 7+) machine with problems (not difference):
- DLL's in the C:\Program Files (x86)\MonoGame\v3.0\Assemblies\DesktopGL path are 3.5.1.1679
- DLL's in the C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\MonoGame\v3.0\Tools are 3.5.1.1679
- DLL's in the Debug\ path are 3.5.1.1679

loaded assemblies when dubug(listed only with differences):
- mscorlib.dll 4.6.1080
- System.Core.dll 4.6.1038.0
- System.dll 4.6.1081.0 
- System.Drawing.dll 4.6.1078.0 
- System.Windows.Forms.dll 4.6.1038.0 

Who can investigate?
Dublicate question on SO: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38545272/monogame-texture-without-colors

**UPDATE:** It seems what it only not working on Intel HD Graphics, but on Radeon and NVidia works fine...

data.title: Support Multiple Texture Compression options for Android.
data.body:
The current system we have allows users to specify the TextureCompression directly for android. So if the user wants to ship GPU specific apis [1] they need to build the .apk 3 times. 

This is because they 
1. Need to change the AndroidManifest.xml to specify the GPU they want (as per [1])
2. Rebuild the content with the correct TextureCompression for that GPU (ATI, PVRTC, DXT).

Because the texture compression method would need to be specified manually the user would need to maintain 3 Content.mgcb files. This is not ideal. 

We need to come up with a way of just using "Compressed" for texture and being able to change the default texture compression for Android. It will default to ETC1 for Opaque textures and 16bit RGBA for those with Alpha.

[1] https://developer.android.com/google/play/publishing/multiple-apks.html

data.title: Implemented GraphicsAdapter for DirectX platforms

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
This PR cleans up `GraphicsAdapter` into a partial class allowing for other platforms to cleanly extend it.

Added unit tests to verify the DirectX implementation matches XNA behavior.

Left old implementation of `GraphicsAdapter` in legacy file that is used on the other public platforms.  We should start replacing these with correct partial implementations.

data.title: Buffer boundary stutter using DynamicSoundEffectInstance

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
See [this forum post](http://community.monogame.net/t/just-trying-to-figure-out-how-to-play-a-simple-sin-wave/7938) for a repro.

This was a known issue in the `DynamicSoundEffectInstance` PR (#4715) which I was not able to pin down. It seems to occur both on XAudio and OpenAL, but I don't know if the issue is in the common code or platform implementations. Any ideas from someone more knowledgeable about audio?

data.title: DynamicSoundEffectInstance is added to all platforms by default
data.body: `DynamicSoundEffectInstance` was only set to be added on DirectX and OpenAL platforms.... this adds it by default on all platforms.

data.title: Fixed AL bindings for DynamicSoundEffectInstance
data.body:
Simple follow up fix after https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/4715 was merged without being rebased to the new AL bindings.

Ran the WindowsGL unit tests and the `DynamicSoundEffectInstance` tests all pass.

    Update- 2 - Initialize

    Draw- 2 - Initialize

Note: removing a component during .Initialize() will have unpredictable results.

data.title: RenderTarget2D throws SharpDXException when width and/or height is great enough
data.body:
After switching from the stable 3.5 release to the latest development build of Monogame, I ran into a few problems. One of them has been resolved already, another has an open issue, #4740, and the last is this.

In my game, in order to avoid drawing a lot of tiles at once, which was eating up CPU, I set it up so that the tiles are drawn to a RenderTarget2D and the RenderTarget2D itself is drawn instead, and only updated as needed when tiles are added or removed. I initialized the RenderTarget2D something like this:

`blocks = new RenderTarget2D(graphics.GraphicsDevice, 10000, 10000);`

With 3.5, this works fine. But with the latest build, it throws a SharpDXException, with the following information (I edited out the irrelevant parts of the stack trace):

> SharpDX.SharpDXException was unhandled
>   HResult=-2147024809
>   Message=HRESULT: [0x80070057], Module: [General], ApiCode: [E_INVALIDARG/Invalid Arguments], Message: The parameter is incorrect.
> 
>   Source=SharpDX
>   StackTrace:
>        at SharpDX.Result.CheckError()
>        at SharpDX.Direct3D11.Device.CreateTexture2D(Texture2DDescription& descRef, DataBox[] initialDataRef, Texture2D texture2DOut)
>        at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D.CreateTexture()
>        at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTarget2D.GenerateIfRequired()
>   InnerException: 

Further experimentation showed that the exception is directly related to the size of the RenderTarget2D being initialized. Constructing it at a much smaller width and height works fine. I did some testing and found the point where the exception is thrown.

This constructor works fine.

`blocks = new RenderTarget2D(graphics.GraphicsDevice, 4096, 4096);`

This constructor throws the exception.

`blocks = new RenderTarget2D(graphics.GraphicsDevice, 4097, 4096);`

4096 is a very binary number... That doesn't seem like a coincidence. Is this a bug or a correct limit to the size of a RenderTarget2D?

data.title: Adds Vector3.TransformCoord #4587
data.body:
By reading the documentation of XMVector3TransformCoord and comparing the other Transform methods in MonoGame, I think this is what is asked on #4587 .

I assume this is the way to keep the w component 1.0.

data.title: XML doc for Matrix.Add contradicts what the code actually does
data.body:
The XML doc says it creates a new Matrix but the code actually just puts the result in matrix1 and returns it.

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Matrix.cs#L425

Is this method supposed to create a new Matrix (code is incorrect) or is it supposed to put the result in matrix1 (XML doc is incorrect)?

data.title: Update coding policy for MonoDevelop / Xamarin Studio 6
data.body: The file is used to autoset code formating when opening with MonoDevelop/Xamarin Studio, there were some changes with version 6.

data.title: SoundEffectInstance.PlatformApply3D() generates garbage.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body: SharpDXHalper.ToEmitter() and SharpDXHalper.ToListener() allocates new instance of SharpDX.X3DAudio.Emitter in every call to PlatrformApply3D(). It seems to me that it is against the goal of allocation-free framework. Especially since Apply3D() is expected to be called every frame for multiple sounds.

data.title: SoundEffectInstance.XAudio changed to lower memory allocation.
data.body:
X3DAudio Emitter and Listener are cached to prevent memory allocation
for every Apply3D call.

This is a quick and dirty "correction" so it should be refactored in future as long as you approve this approach. I think we should aim for allocation-free solutions where possible.

Fixes https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/5015.

data.title: Change the Default texture compression for Models to Compressed
data.body:
The default was DXTCompressed. This does not work on
iOS. To make it easier we should default to
Compressed so that the default for the target
platform is used.

data.title: Pipeline tool crashes when selecting an Effect (develop)
data.body:
I was doing a test and the Pipeline tool crashes when selecting an Effect in the tree.
I traced this down to 

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Tools/Pipeline/Controls/PropertyGridTable.cs#L132

At this point "type" is null. so when we try to figure out the type is crashes. It happens when trying to figure out the "Defines" property on the Effect, which has a value of null. 

The question is how to fix it. Should we default all unknown types to string?

@cra0zy ? any ideas,

data.title: Reset effectMaterial.Effect to null so we do not try to serialize it.
data.body:
There was a bug when serializing the effectMaterial.
After we had compiled the effect it was still trying
to serialize the actual Effect object as well not
just the CompiledEffect.
So we null it out after compilation to make sure
we dont serialize it.

As part of these changes I added a bunch more unit tests for creating `SoundEffect` via constructors and and `SoundEffect.FromStream`.

data.title: [UWP] Windows Store certification issue regarding SharpDX.MediaFoundation
data.body:
I tried to update my UWP app a few days ago, and the update kept failing the certification because of an error:

```
Error Found: The supported APIs test detected the following errors:
API MFCreateAggregateSource in mf.dll is not supported for this application type. SharpDX.MediaFoundation.dll calls this API.
API MFGetService in mf.dll is not supported for this application type. SharpDX.MediaFoundation.dll calls this API.
```

And it seems I'm not the only one experiencing this issue, as discussed in this [thread](http://community.monogame.net/t/store-certification-issues-regarding-sharpdx-mediafoundation/7862).

data.title: .WMA files along with .XNB files in content/bin
data.body:
Whenever I add a song to my content app, no matter if it's MP3/WAV/WMA I get a .WMA file of the same song together with the XNBs. So I've never published a Monogame project from VS and I guess in the final product there shouldn't be any .WMA files in that folder, right? Otherwise it would be too easy to steal copyrighted songs, for instance. I remember XNA having identical behavior too. So can someone shed some light on this? I don't see .PNG files where my texture XNBs are, neither I see .WAV files where my sounds are... So this only happens with songs. Why?

![Screenshot](http://i.stack.imgur.com/vZDEi.png)

data.title: Refactored audio processing for platform extensibility

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
This is a follow up to #4992 and #4996.

Here I've added a new `AudioProfile` and `DefaultAudioProfile` classes which do the work previously found in `AudioContent`.

Like with the work on shader processing and textures... one just need to implement a new instance of `AudioProfile` to add support for converting audio to a new format for a new platform.

As part of this I added a bunch of unit tests for `WavImporter` and `AudioContent` to ensure we've compatible with XNA behavior.

Note that conversion to MSADPCM doesn't result in the exact final sample rates as XNA.  For this reason I worked around those checks in the test.  We need someone else to go investigate and figure this out eventually...  but it isn't critical IMO.

Fixes https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4283.

data.title: Mouse.SetPosition for UWP
data.body:
Yes, it's possible, the code is:

``` c#
Window.Current.CoreWindow.PointerPosition = new Windows.Foundation.Point(100, 100);
```

It works with the standard UWP Blank template, but it doesn't work in the MG Template (It still moves the mouse, but it moves it to 0, 0)  Since I don't fully know how the UWP app works under the hood I leave this here so that someone else may add this part of the API.
